Phoenix, Arizona 6 - 11 October 1991 Organizer: Bob Marcus The main outcome of the end-users BOF at 
OOPSLA was the formation of an ongoing group tentatively named Corporate Facilitators of Object-Oriented 
Technology (CFOOT). The purpose of the group is to communicate corporate requirements to vendors and 
consortia. In addition, the group will provide a mechanism for sharing experiences and lessons learned 
in introducing object technology into large corporations. A possible motto for the group is: Object-oriented 
Technology + Business Case + Migration Plan = Success . One of the first activities of the group will 
be trying to organize a Smalltalk workshop in the Pacific Northwest around the time of OOPSLA 1992. To 
get on the group s mailing list contact Bob Marcus at (X)6)865-3189 or rmarcus@atc.boeing.com . As part 
of the initial meeting, a list of end-user requirements for vendors was gathered by brainstorming. These 
are: 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6.  Consider your products as components of larger and/or legacy systems. Focus 
on areas where your product can add value. Avoid unnecessary proprietary features and interfaces. Interoperate 
with other products and components. Plan to interface with multiple legacy platforms, systems, processes 
and organizations. Supply tools for supporting total life cycle project management, methodologies and 
metrics. Provide robust class libraries to encapsulate non-object-oriented systems. Supply tools for 
reverse engineering and code generation Provide object-oriented screen painters and robust standardized 
classes for graphical user interfaces. 10. Supply source code for class libraries using a reasonable, 
coherent pricing structure. Addendum to the Proceedings OOPSLA 91 [971
